awd_titl_txt: Investigation of the Causal Relationship Between Chromatin Structure Fluctuations and Gene Expression Noise by Electron and Fluorescence Microscopy
awd_abstract_narration:
Intellectual Merit: Animal, plant and fungal cells alike package their DNA by spooling it in regular intervals about a protein core, forming a jointed chain of DNA spools (nucleosomes). The spooling renders the DNA less accessible and thus interferes with the reading of its genetic information. How then does DNA spooling affect gene activity and regulation? This research addresses this question by investigating the structure of isolated single-gene molecules and gene expression at the single cell level. The essential tools for this research are electron and fluorescence microscopy, combined with mathematical modeling, and yeast genetics. Surprisingly, recent studies have provided evidence that active genes randomly toggle between states during which the gene is either ON or OFF, rather than being on all the time. This random toggling causes the number of gene products produced from a single gene to fluctuate over time. These fluctuations can provide insight into how the gene is activated, but the molecular basis of ON/Off toggling is not understood. One possibility is that random spooling and unspooling of DNA--analogous to the continued opening and closing of a door at randomly chosen time points--may underlie the ON/OFF toggling of active genes. Testing of this hypothesis requires analysis of DNA spooling at the level of single gene molecules. To this end, this research will investigate the structure of specific genes within single cells of baker's yeast by isolation of the gene molecules and subsequent analysis by electron microscopy. The molecules will be isolated from cells that bear mutations in critical biochemical components for DNA spooling, including the proteins that make up the core of the DNA spool. These structural investigations will be combined with analysis of gene expression of single cells by fluorescence microscopy and mathematical modeling to reveal the dynamics and functional significance of DNA spooling for gene expression and regulation. 

Broader Impacts: In this project a postdoctoral fellow and one graduate student will be trained. In addition, undergraduate students will be trained through academic-year or summer internships.  Student interns will be recruited from underrepresented groups through existing campus programs. These students will be overseen by the PIs, both directly in the lab and in biweekly joint group meetings, and by the post-doctoral fellow and the graduate students of this project. Students will be trained in fluorescence and electron microscopy, yeast genetics and, importantly, in approaching biological problems by quantitative means. Daily interactions with scientists at different stages of their careers will benefit the undergraduates through multiple layers of supervision and will allow the graduate student and post-doctoral trainees to have the opportunity to supervise beginning students. The graduate student and post-doctoral trainee will be given the opportunity to present their work locally and at national meetings.

This project is co-funded by the Genetic Mechanisms Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and by the Applied Mathematics and Mathematical Biology Programs in the Division of Mathematical Sciences.

por.por_cntn:
In this last year of the award, I obtained a no-cost extension to allow Robert Shelansky to finish and write up his Ph.D. thesis. Robert graduated in the midst of a campus evacuation due to wildfire that had threatened the main campus and after months of shutdown due to the covid-19 pandemic.

 Results obtained over the period of this award have been disseminated in eleven publications (Boeger, 2014; Boeger et al., 2015; Brown and Boeger, 2014; Brown et al., 2013, 2015; Dhillon et al., 2020; Fei et al., 2015; Hamperl et al., 2013, 2014; Le et al., 2019; Shelansky and Boeger, 2020) and numerous invited talks, within US and outside (Germany and Israel).

Over the NSF-funded period, I have trained one postdoc, two graduate students, and eleven undergraduate students (among them four minority students, six women, two double majors in biology and mathematics). Five of them have gone on to join Ph.D. programs; two were admitted to medical school. Two local high school students joined us for the summer months.

 The major technical achievement has been the analysis of promoter chromatin at the level of single gene molecules (Brown et al., 2015). Standard methods for analysis of chromatin structure average across gene populations (e.g., probing nuclease accessibility). As a result of averaging, the transition between repressed and active promoter chromatin has been seen as a qualitative, deterministic transformation between static states, between 'closed' and 'open' chromatin. Our electron microscopic and theoretical analysis of PHO5 of yeast led to a different conclusion (Brown et al., 2013): Active promoter chromatin is dynamic, and not static. Promoters continually visit alternative nucleosome configurations in random sequence -- some conducive to transcription and others not. In addition, we found that the structural variation of promoter chromatin arises locally; i.e., it is not the result of fluctuations in cellular state (Brown and Boeger, 2014).

While the purpose of nucleosome removal for transcription is evident, the purpose of nucleosome reformation in activating conditions is not. Both nucleosome formation and removal are catalyzed by ATP-dependent chromatin remodelers. In steady state, the net results appears to be no other than ATP hydrolysis.

We recently suggested a theory that explains our and many other findings: The stochastic and reformation of promoter nucleosomes is part of a mechanism that kinetically proofreads the identity of transcriptional activators (Shelansky and Boeger, 2020): The mechanism enhances specificity not by increasing the energetic difference between correct and incorrect activator-promoter associations but by exploiting the same difference twice: before a delay step, nucleosome removal, and afterward. The removal of promoter nucleosomes by ATP-dependent chromatin remodelers recruited to the promoter by activators drives the structural dynamics of the promoter away from equilibrium, while dissociation of the activator and loss of remodelers from the promoter allows for free energy dissipation by nucleosome reformation. The mechanism might help explain an apparent paradox: While activators regulate the transcription of genes with great specificity, the energetic differences between correct and incorrect sequence-binding are suprisingly small for many eukaryotic (but not prokaryotic) transcriptional activators.

 


Last Modified: 07/17/2021
Modified by: Hinrich Boeger
